title: Tosafot on Bava Metzia
text: Come and hear, (if) he finds money, etc. - Tema (this is surprising), because  this problem was already taught in our mishna with reference to dispersed coins. Why does the baraita ask this once more? And also rabbi Yitzhak, why didn't he use his argument in the mishna (and uses it here instead)? It can be answered that the baraita presents a stronger issue (than the one discussed in the mishna); because it teaches that in every case (the found coins) belong to him (to the one that finds them), even in the case when there is no distinguishing mark, and it expounds the reason: because many people are (usually to be) found in that place. And it says that this is the case also if, when (the one who finds the coins) picked them up, the owner was still in the bet hamidrash, and didn't know they had fallen from him.

The Gemara uses this particular language because of Bat Sheva was a doubtfully married woman. Rashi interpreted that it is because ever man who went to one of David’s wars signed a Gett, on the condition that if he dies, she will be expelled and she would not require יבום (divorce), and all of the days he is out at war she would be considered doubtfully married. And this is a difficulty for Rabeinu Tam that if this is so, it is not “all men”, it is only if they had brothers and did not have children. However, Rashi is not particular when he says “יבום”, rather she will not be tied down (become an Agunah).
And some say 46 - there are those who explain this because they count "because you were strangers in Egypt" and similar ones.

King Shapur -- The correct explanation appears to accord with Rashi (that King Shapur here refers to the actual King Shapur, not the sage Shemuel who is sometimes called King Shapur), for King Shapur was an expert in Jewish law, as it says at the end of Tractate Avodah Zarah (76b), that he stabbed the knife ten times into hard earth when he cut the citron with a knife for Rav Yehudah.
